greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of distinct zeros of x^3-x-1 mod prime(n).
comment: For the prime modulus 23, the polynomial can be factored as (x+13)^2 (x+20), showing that x=10 is a zero of multiplicity 2. The discriminant of the polynomial is -23. - _T. D. Noe_, Aug 12 2004
link: G. C. Greubel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
J.-P. Serre, On a theorem of Jordan, Bull. Amer. Math. Soc., 40 (No. 4, 2003), 429-440, see pp. 433-434.
mathematica: Table[p=Prime[n]; cnt=0; Do[If[Mod[x^3-x-1, p]==0, cnt++ ], {x, 0, p-1}]; cnt, {n, 100}] (* _T. D. Noe_, Aug 12 2004 *)
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, Sep 24 2003
